Commit 46cd9b3: Initial commit from Create Next App

This is the initial commit from Create Next App, setting up a new Next.js project with TypeScript, ESLint, and Tailwind CSS. The project includes a basic README, .gitignore, and package-lock.json files, as well as a next.config.ts file for configuring the Next.js app.
keyDecisions: Setting up a new Next.js project with TypeScript
Using ESLint for code linting and Tailwind CSS for styling
Configuring the Next.js app using the next.config.ts file

architecturalCallouts.title: Using a FlatCompat ESLint configuration
architecturalCallouts.description: The project uses a FlatCompat ESLint configuration, which is a lightweight and modular approach to ESLint configuration. This design decision allows for easy customization and extension of the ESLint configuration.

architecturalCallouts.title: Using a package-lock.json file
architecturalCallouts.description: The project includes a package-lock.json file, which is used to lock down the dependencies of the project. This is a common pattern in Node.js projects to ensure reproducibility and consistency of dependencies.

architecturalCallouts.title: Using Web Vitals for performance optimization
architecturalCallouts.description: The project includes the `next/core-web-vitals` ESLint configuration, which is used to optimize the performance of the Next.js app. This is a best practice for ensuring a fast and responsive user experience.

architecturalCallouts.title: Setting up a new Next.js project
architecturalCallouts.description: This commit provides a starting point for learning how to set up a new Next.js project from scratch. The included files and configurations provide a solid foundation for building a Next.js app.

default.aiSummary: This commit initializes a new Next.js project using the Create Next App tooling, establishing foundational project structure, configuration files, and dependency management. Core components include standard .gitignore patterns, ESLint configuration for TypeScript and Next.js best practices, and basic project scaffolding for a React 19 + Next.js 15.5.4 application.
keyDecisions: Adopted Next.js 15.5.4 with React 19.1.0 as the core framework
Integrated TypeScript 5 for type safety
Configured ESLint with @eslint/eslintrc and FlatCompat for configuration compatibility
Established standard .gitignore patterns for Next.js and Node.js development
Prepared Tailwind CSS 4 integration through devDependencies

architecturalCallouts.title: Next.js Project Scaffolding
architecturalCallouts.description: Initialized project structure using Create Next App tooling, ensuring standard directory layout and essential configuration files for optimal Next.js development workflow

architecturalCallouts.title: FlatCompat ESLint Configuration
architecturalCallouts.description: Implemented FlatCompat to maintain compatibility with existing ESLint configuration patterns while adopting the new flat config format introduced in ESLint 9

architecturalCallouts.title: TypeScript Integration
architecturalCallouts.description: Added TypeScript 5 with corresponding type definitions for React 19 and Node.js 20, establishing type safety as a core development practice

architecturalCallouts.title: Core Web Vitals Configuration
architecturalCallouts.description: Pre-configured ESLint to enforce Next.js core web vitals best practices through the 'next/core-web-vitals' configuration preset

default.aiSummary: This commit initializes a new Next.js project, setting up the basic project structure, configuration files, and dependencies. It includes the creation of a .gitignore file, a README.md file with project documentation, an ESLint configuration, a Next.js configuration file, and the package-lock.json with initial dependencies.
keyDecisions: Choosing Next.js as the framework for the project.

architecturalCallouts.title: Next.js Framework Usage
architecturalCallouts.description: The project uses Next.js, a React-based framework with built-in support for server-side rendering and static site generation, to build the web application.

architecturalCallouts.title: ESLint Configuration
architecturalCallouts.description: The project sets up ESLint with specific ignores and extends configurations to maintain code quality and consistency.

architecturalCallouts.title: Project Initialization
architecturalCallouts.description: The commit demonstrates the initial setup of a Next.js project, including necessary configuration files and dependency management.

default.aiSummary: The initial commit sets up a brand‑new Next.js application using the create‑next‑app scaffold. It adds core project files (.gitignore, README, next.config.ts, ESLint flat config), pulls in Next.js v15.5.4 with React 19, and includes TypeScript, Tailwind CSS, and related development dependencies. The commit establishes the baseline project structure, tooling, and configuration needed for future feature development, while also documenting how to run and deploy the app.
keyDecisions: Adopt Next.js (v15.5.4) as the primary framework for the web application.
Use TypeScript as the language for type‑safety and developer productivity.
Configure ESLint with the new flat config format and extend Next.js core‑web‑vitals rules.
Include Tailwind CSS as a styling solution (added as a devDependency).
Leverage next/font (Geist) for automatic font optimization.
Set up a minimal .gitignore to exclude build artefacts, node_modules, and environment files.

architecturalCallouts.title: Framework Selection – Next.js
architecturalCallouts.description: Choosing Next.js provides built‑in routing, server‑side rendering, and static site generation, aligning the project with modern React best practices and Vercel deployment workflows.

architecturalCallouts.title: TypeScript Integration
architecturalCallouts.description: Including TypeScript from the start ensures static typing across the codebase, reducing runtime errors and improving IDE support.

architecturalCallouts.title: Flat ESLint Configuration
architecturalCallouts.description: The project adopts ESLint’s flat config (eslint.config.mjs) with compatibility helpers, simplifying rule management and supporting future modular rule sets.

architecturalCallouts.title: Scaffolding via create‑next‑app
architecturalCallouts.description: Using the official Next.js starter establishes a conventional file layout (app/, public/, etc.) and includes starter scripts for development and deployment.

architecturalCallouts.title: next/font Automatic Optimization
architecturalCallouts.description: The README mentions next/font, which loads the Geist font with built‑in optimization (preloading, subsetting), improving initial paint performance.

architecturalCallouts.title: Lint Ignoring Build Directories
architecturalCallouts.description: The ESLint config explicitly ignores .next, out, and build folders, preventing unnecessary lint passes on generated files and speeding up CI.

architecturalCallouts.title: Initial Dependency Footprint
architecturalCallouts.description: The generated package‑lock shows a large set of transitive dev dependencies (eslint, tailwindcss, @types/*). Understanding this baseline helps anticipate future upgrade or pruning efforts.

architecturalCallouts.title: Future Tailwind Integration
architecturalCallouts.description: Tailwind CSS is added as a dev dependency but not yet configured; developers will need to create tailwind.config.ts and add the PostCSS plugin to fully enable utility‑first styling.

This commit updates the filters feature, removing the analytics page and replacing it with a new set of filters and sorting options. The update includes a new design for the tech stack grid and improved performance by reducing the number of API calls.
keyDecisions: Refactored the filters feature to improve performance
Removed the analytics page and replaced it with a new set of filters and sorting options
Updated the design of the tech stack grid for better user experience

architecturalCallouts.title: Improved performance by reducing API calls
architecturalCallouts.description: The commit updated the code to fetch data from the API only once, reducing the number of API calls and improving performance.

architecturalCallouts.title: Used memoization to improve performance
architecturalCallouts.description: The code used memoization to cache the results of expensive function calls, reducing the number of API calls and improving performance.

architecturalCallouts.title: Learned about the importance of caching in improving performance
architecturalCallouts.description: The commit highlighted the importance of caching in improving performance, especially when dealing with large datasets or expensive function calls.

architecturalCallouts.title: Updated the design of the tech stack grid
architecturalCallouts.description: The commit updated the design of the tech stack grid to make it more user-friendly and visually appealing.

architecturalCallouts.title: Identified opportunities to improve performance
architecturalCallouts.description: The commit identified opportunities to improve performance by reducing the number of API calls and using memoization to cache results.

default.aiSummary: The commit removes the analytics page component responsible for displaying technology stack trends across projects. This page previously handled client-side data fetching, filtering by category, sorting by usage/name, and visualizing project statistics with UI components like badges and progress bars. The deletion suggests a refactoring or architectural shift in how analytics are presented, potentially consolidating functionality or rethinking data visualization approach.
keyDecisions: Removed client-side analytics page to simplify architecture or consolidate features
Eliminated category filtering and sorting logic from frontend implementation
Deprecated custom UI components for tech stack visualization in favor of new approach

architecturalCallouts.title: Client Component Removal
architecturalCallouts.description: Removed 'use client' component that handled analytics visualization, indicating a shift toward server-side rendering or external analytics integration

architecturalCallouts.title: TypeScript Interfaces
architecturalCallouts.description: Defined TechUsageStats interface for type safety, demonstrating commitment to strongly-typed data handling

architecturalCallouts.title: Client-Side Filtering
architecturalCallouts.description: Previously implemented filtering/sorting in browser - removal suggests performance optimization by shifting this logic server-side

architecturalCallouts.title: UI/UX Patterns
architecturalCallouts.description: Used progressive disclosure patterns with loading/error states and categorized data visualization techniques

default.aiSummary: This commit removes an outdated client-side analytics page and updates the filtering system, likely in favor of a more modern, server-side component architecture. The change simplifies the codebase and improves maintainability.
keyDecisions: Remove client-side analytics component to simplify the codebase.
Implement a new filtering system to enhance user experience.

architecturalCallouts.title: Server Component Adoption
architecturalCallouts.description: The commit removes client-side rendering and adopts a server-side component approach, reducing client-side logic and improving performance.

default.aiSummary: In this commit the team removed the large client‑side analytics page (src/app/analytics/page.tsx) that displayed technology usage statistics, and refreshed the repository data file (.data/repos.db). The removal suggests a refactor of the analytics UI—likely moving the logic to a different route, simplifying filter handling, or shifting to a server‑rendered approach. The change aligns with a broader effort to streamline the codebase, reduce bundle size, and improve the maintainability of filter logic across the application.
keyDecisions: Delete the client‑side analytics page component to simplify the UI and reduce bundle weight.
Refresh the repository database file, indicating an update to the underlying data set used by analytics.
Consolidate or redesign filter handling (as implied by the commit message "update filters").

architecturalCallouts.title: Remove heavy client component
architecturalCallouts.description: The analytics page, which performed data fetching with useEffect and rendered complex UI, was deleted. This reduces the client bundle size and shifts responsibility for data aggregation to a different layer (likely server‑side or a dedicated component).

architecturalCallouts.title: Client‑side data fetching with useEffect
architecturalCallouts.description: The removed page used the classic React pattern of fetching data in a useEffect hook, handling loading, error, and state updates. This pattern is now being reconsidered in favor of server‑side data fetching or React Server Components.

architecturalCallouts.title: Bundle size and initial load improvement
architecturalCallouts.description: By deleting the large analytics page, the initial JavaScript payload sent to the browser is reduced, leading to faster page loads and lower memory usage on client devices.

architecturalCallouts.title: Importance of modular filter UI
architecturalCallouts.description: The commit message "update filters" and the removal of filter UI code highlight a lesson that filter components should be modular and reusable across pages, prompting a redesign to avoid duplication.

architecturalCallouts.title: Data store update
architecturalCallouts.description: A binary change to .data/repos.db suggests the analytics data source was refreshed, indicating a decision to keep the analytics dataset current and possibly to decouple data updates from UI code.

default.aiSummary: Commit b399882: update filters

This commit introduces a comprehensive integration of GitHub Copilot CLI for repository analysis, replacing the previous document-based approach. The system now clones repositories, leverages Copilot's code-aware analysis, and provides structured insights (summary, technical observations, and actionable recommendations). Key features include temporary clone management, fallback error handling, and setup instructions for Copilot CLI. The implementation emphasizes full codebase context understanding, improved dependency/architecture analysis, and performance optimizations like shallow clones.
keyDecisions: Adopted GitHub Copilot CLI for full codebase analysis instead of markdown-only document parsing
Used temporary directories with automatic cleanup to handle repository cloning securely
Implemented a fallback mechanism to LM Studio when Copilot CLI is unavailable or fails
Structured analysis output into standardized JSON format (summary, insights, actions)
Prioritized shallow clones (--depth 1) to reduce analysis latency for large repositories

architecturalCallouts.title: Modular Component Separation
architecturalCallouts.description: Created dedicated modules (repo-cloner.ts, copilot-analyzer.ts) to isolate cloning, analysis, and cleanup logic, improving maintainability and testability.

architecturalCallouts.title: Shallow Clone Optimization
architecturalCallouts.description: Used --depth 1 cloning to minimize repository size and reduce clone times while maintaining sufficient context for analysis.

architecturalCallouts.title: Try-Catch-Finally Workflow
architecturalCallouts.description: Wrapped analysis logic in try-catch-finally blocks to ensure repository cleanup occurs even if analysis fails.

architecturalCallouts.title: Standardized Analysis Output
architecturalCallouts.description: Defined a consistent JSON response structure (summary, insights, actions) to unify output across different analysis methods (Copilot CLI vs LM Studio).

architecturalCallouts.title: Context-Aware Analysis
architecturalCallouts.description: Leveraged Copilot CLI's ability to analyze code structure, dependencies, and architecture patterns for richer insights compared to document-only approaches.

architecturalCallouts.title: Token Scope Requirements
architecturalCallouts.description: Learned that GITHUB_TOKEN must include the 'repo' scope for cloning private repositories, requiring updated documentation and configuration guidance.

default.aiSummary: A comprehensive summary of the commit: The commit introduces GitHub Copilot CLI integration, allowing for AI-powered repository analysis. The new integration uses Copilot to analyze the entire codebase, including code structure, dependencies, and architecture patterns. This provides a more comprehensive understanding of the project, enabling users to make informed decisions about improvements. The system has been updated to support shallow clones, authentication via GitHub token, and caching to improve performance.
keyDecisions: Decided to use GitHub Copilot CLI for AI-powered repository analysis
Implemented shallow clones to improve performance
Updated API endpoint to use Copilot CLI instead of LM Studio
Added fallback mechanism for Copilot CLI errors

architecturalCallouts.title: Design Decision: Use of GitHub Copilot CLI
architecturalCallouts.description: The commit introduces the use of GitHub Copilot CLI for repository analysis, providing a more comprehensive understanding of the project.

architecturalCallouts.title: Pattern-Used: Shallow Clones
architecturalCallouts.description: The system uses shallow clones to improve performance and reduce analysis time.

architecturalCallouts.title: Performance Insight: Using shallow clones
architecturalCallouts.description: The use of shallow clones reduces the time required for repository analysis, making the system more responsive.

architecturalCallouts.title: Learning: Error Handling and Fallback Mechanism
architecturalCallouts.description: The commit highlights the importance of error handling and fallback mechanisms in ensuring a smooth user experience, even in the presence of errors.

architecturalCallouts.title: Design Decision: Caching
architecturalCallouts.description: The system is designed to store Copilot analysis results, reducing the need for re-cloning on every request and improving performance.

default.aiSummary: The commit introduces a new local AI analysis pipeline that replaces the previous LM Studio document‑based approach with GitHub Copilot CLI. New utilities were added to clone repositories shallowly into temporary directories, invoke Copilot for full‑codebase analysis, parse its JSON output, and clean up afterwards. The API route handling repository data was updated to orchestrate this workflow, and extensive documentation and a verification script were added. The changes improve analysis depth, provide richer insights, and include robust error handling with a fallback mechanism.
keyDecisions: Switch repository analysis from LM Studio markdown parsing to GitHub Copilot CLI for full codebase insight.
Implement shallow cloning (--depth 1) to minimize I/O and speed up analysis.
Introduce a dedicated repo‑cloner module to handle cloning and cleanup, ensuring resources are released even on failure.
Encapsulate Copilot interactions in a copilot‑analyzer module, abstracting CLI details from the API layer.
Provide a fallback response when Copilot CLI is unavailable, preserving API contract.
Add environment variable configuration (GITHUB_TOKEN, AI_MODEL, LM_STUDIO_URL) and a verification script to ensure required tools are installed and authenticated.

architecturalCallouts.title: Full‑Repository AI Analysis via Copilot CLI
architecturalCallouts.description: The system now clones the entire repository and passes it to the GitHub Copilot CLI, allowing analysis of code structure, dependencies, and architecture rather than just markdown files.

architecturalCallouts.title: Separation of Concerns with Repo‑Cloner Service
architecturalCallouts.description: A new `src/lib/repo-cloner.ts` module centralizes cloning, shallow clone options, authentication handling, and cleanup, making the workflow reusable and testable.

architecturalCallouts.title: Adapter/Facade Pattern for AI Engine
architecturalCallouts.description: `src/lib/copilot-analyzer.ts` acts as an adapter that translates the Copilot CLI's output into the internal `RepoAnalysis` format, isolating the rest of the codebase from CLI specifics.

architecturalCallouts.title: Try‑Finally Cleanup Pattern
architecturalCallouts.description: The API route wraps the clone‑analyze sequence in a `try...finally` block to guarantee that temporary directories are removed even if analysis throws an error.

architecturalCallouts.title: Shallow Clone for Faster Execution
architecturalCallouts.description: Using `git clone --depth 1` reduces network transfer and disk usage, cutting typical clone times to a few seconds and keeping analysis latency within 10‑30 seconds for larger projects.

architecturalCallouts.title: Resource Hygiene via Automatic Cleanup
architecturalCallouts.description: Ensuring temporary repository directories are deleted prevents disk bloat on the server, maintaining long‑term performance and stability.

architecturalCallouts.title: Importance of GitHub Token Scope
architecturalCallouts.description: The integration highlighted that the `GITHUB_TOKEN` must include the `repo` scope to clone private repositories, a detail now documented in setup guides.

architecturalCallouts.title: Fallback Strategy to Preserve API Contract
architecturalCallouts.description: Implementing a structured fallback JSON response when Copilot CLI fails taught the value of graceful degradation, ensuring client applications continue to receive predictable data.

default.aiSummary: This commit introduces support for GitHub Copilot CLI integration, enabling AI-powered repository analysis. The project now clones repositories, leverages Copilot for comprehensive insights, and ensures cleanup of temporary clones. Key features include setup documentation, new library functions, API route updates, and a fallback mechanism.
keyDecisions: Decided to integrate GitHub Copilot CLI for repository analysis, replacing previous document-based approach.
Implemented shallow cloning for performance and cleanup efficiency.
Designed fallback mechanisms for authentication and error handling.
Decided to use dependency injection for logging and configuration management.

architecturalCallouts.title: Switch to Copilot CLI Integration
architecturalCallouts.description: The project now uses GitHub Copilot CLI for AI analysis, which involves cloning repositories, running Copilot commands, and ensuring cleanup. This replaces the previous method of analyzing only markdown documents.

architecturalCallouts.title: Singleton Pattern
architecturalCallouts.description: The `RepoAnalyzer` class uses the singleton pattern to ensure there is only one instance handling analysis, improving performance and reducing resource usage.

architecturalCallouts.title: Shallow Cloning for Efficiency
architecturalCallouts.description: The implementation uses shallow clones (via `--depth 1`) to minimize disk usage and reduce analysis time, enhancing overall performance.

architecturalCallouts.title: Authentication and Token Handling
architecturalCallouts.description: The system requires a GitHub token with repo scope for cloning private repositories, emphasizing the importance of proper authentication setup.

default.aiSummary: Commit 721fc53: Add local AI analysis

This commit adds project statistics, updates dependencies, and introduces several new components from the Radix UI library. It appears to be a significant step in enhancing the project's performance and user experience.
keyDecisions: Decided to use Radix UI library for improved performance and user experience
Updated dependencies to latest versions for better compatibility and security

architecturalCallouts.title: Radix UI Library Integration
architecturalCallouts.description: The project has decided to integrate the Radix UI library to improve performance and user experience. This decision is expected to have a significant impact on the project's overall architecture and development pace.

architecturalCallouts.title: Dependency Management
architecturalCallouts.description: The project has adopted a standardized approach to dependency management, updating dependencies to their latest versions and using peer dependencies to ensure compatibility and security.

architecturalCallouts.title: Radix UI Library Performance Benefits
architecturalCallouts.description: The integration of the Radix UI library is expected to provide significant performance benefits, including improved rendering and animation performance, as well as enhanced accessibility features.

architecturalCallouts.title: React Version Upgrade
architecturalCallouts.description: The project has upgraded from React 19.1.0 to 19.2.0, which may require adjustments to existing code and may introduce new features and performance improvements.

default.aiSummary: This commit introduces significant updates to project dependencies and adds Radix UI components for enhanced interactivity. Key changes include upgrading React to v19.2.0, integrating @radix-ui/react-toggle-group for UI controls, and updating dev tools like ESLint and TypeScript. The addition of Radix UI primitives (collection, context, roving focus) suggests implementing complex component patterns requiring accessibility and composition. Overall, the focus was on modernizing the tech stack while laying groundwork for reusable, accessible UI patterns.
keyDecisions: Adopted Radix UI's toggle-group component for enhanced UI controls
Upgraded React and React DOM to version 19.2.0 for new features and performance improvements
Standardized development tools with updated ESLint, Tailwind, and TypeScript versions
Integrated Radix UI's foundational primitives for building composable components

architecturalCallouts.title: Radix UI Integration Strategy
architecturalCallouts.description: Chose Radix UI's composable components over custom solutions to improve accessibility and maintainability in toggle interactions

architecturalCallouts.title: Composable Refs Pattern
architecturalCallouts.description: Implemented @radix-ui/react-compose-refs to safely combine multiple ref handlers in component patterns

architecturalCallouts.title: Primitive Optimization
architecturalCallouts.description: Used Radix's low-level primitives (react-primitive) to reduce unnecessary re-renders in UI components

architecturalCallouts.title: Dependency Version Management
architecturalCallouts.description: Confirmed importance of keeping dependencies aligned with peerDependencies to avoid compatibility issues during major upgrades

default.aiSummary: This commit adds project statistics functionality and updates various dependencies. It includes updates to React, TypeScript, Tailwind CSS, and adds new Radix UI components. The changes improve development tools and user interface elements.
keyDecisions: Bumped React and related dependencies to version 19.2.0 for improved functionality and performance.
Added Radix UI components and related libraries for enhanced UI development.

architecturalCallouts.title: Dependency Version Update
architecturalCallouts.description: Updated React, TypeScript, and Tailwind CSS versions to leverage new features and performance improvements.

architecturalCallouts.title: Radix UI Integration
architecturalCallouts.description: Integrated Radix UI components for modern and reusable user interface elements.

architecturalCallouts.title: Versioning and Dependency Management
architecturalCallouts.description: Learned best practices for versioning dependencies and maintaining development tools.

default.aiSummary: The commit introduces a new "project stats" feature and brings in the Radix UI component library, notably @radix-ui/react-toggle-group, to support the UI for this feature. It also upgrades the core React version to 19.2.0 and bumps several related dependencies and dev tools (ESLint, Tailwind, TypeScript, @types packages) to their latest releases. The extensive changes in package-lock.json reflect the addition of multiple Radix UI primitives and utilities, preparing the codebase for accessible, composable UI components needed by the stats view.
keyDecisions: Add a project statistics feature to the application.
Adopt Radix UI components (toggle group and related primitives) for accessible UI.
Upgrade React and React‑DOM to version 19.2.0.
Update dev dependencies (ESLint, Tailwind, TypeScript, @types) to newer releases.

architecturalCallouts.title: Use Radix UI toggle group for stats UI
architecturalCallouts.description: The project now depends on @radix-ui/react-toggle-group and a suite of Radix primitives, indicating a decision to build the stats interface with accessible, composable components provided by Radix.

architecturalCallouts.title: Upgrade core React version
architecturalCallouts.description: React and React‑DOM are bumped from 19.1.0 to 19.2.0, aligning the app with the latest React features and performance improvements.

architecturalCallouts.title: Component composition via Radix primitives
architecturalCallouts.description: The added Radix packages (react-collection, react-compose-refs, react-context, etc.) enable a pattern of low‑level primitive composition, promoting reusability and consistent accessibility across UI components.

architecturalCallouts.title: Potential bundle size impact from Radix UI
architecturalCallouts.description: Introducing many Radix UI packages will increase the JavaScript bundle size; developers should monitor load performance and consider tree‑shaking or lazy‑loading the stats component.

architecturalCallouts.title: Managing peer dependencies and optional type packages
architecturalCallouts.description: Radix UI packages declare peer dependencies for React and optional @types packages, highlighting the need to keep type definitions in sync and ensure compatibility across React versions.

architecturalCallouts.title: Keeping tooling up‑to‑date
architecturalCallouts.description: Updating ESLint, Tailwind, and TypeScript versions demonstrates the importance of regularly refreshing the development toolchain to benefit from bug fixes and new language features.

default.aiSummary: Today's work focused on implementing project statistics visualization with a polished UI component. The team added a toggle-based stats interface using Radix UI's Toggle Group, allowing users to switch between different data views. This involved upgrading React to 19.2.0 and modernizing several dev dependencies for better TypeScript support and tooling stability. The changes show a clear direction toward enhancing data visualization capabilities while maintaining strict accessibility standards through well-tested UI primitives.
keyDecisions: Adopted Radix UI Toggle Group component for accessible stats view switching instead of building custom solution
Upgraded React to 19.2.0 to leverage latest concurrent rendering features for smoother stats UI interactions
Standardized TypeScript version across all tooling dependencies to eliminate version conflicts in type checking

architecturalCallouts.title: Radix UI for Accessible Toggle Implementation
architecturalCallouts.description: Chose Radix UI's Toggle Group over custom implementation to ensure WCAG-compliant keyboard navigation and focus management for stats view switching, reducing accessibility testing surface while maintaining design flexibility

architecturalCallouts.title: Progressive Dependency Modernization
architecturalCallouts.description: Upgraded dependencies in cohesive groups (React ecosystem + TypeScript toolchain) rather than piecemeal, minimizing version conflict risks while maintaining backward compatibility through minor version updates

architecturalCallouts.title: Selective UI Library Adoption
architecturalCallouts.description: Added only the specific Radix UI toggle component instead of full component library, keeping bundle size impact minimal (70 lines added vs 10 removed) while gaining production-tested accessibility features

architecturalCallouts.title: Version Range Precision in Lockfiles
architecturalCallouts.description: Observed how precise version ranges (^1.1.11) in package-lock.json prevent unexpected breaking changes during dependency updates, validating the team's strict version control policy for UI components
